4.00.text: The Solar system. Our home in space.

9.91.text:
We live in a peaceful
part of the Milky Way.

13.65.text: Our home is the Solar system,

15.48.text:
a 4.5-billion-year-old formation that
races around the galactic centre at

20.56.text:
200,000 km/h and circles it
once every 250 million years.

29.52.text:
Our star, the Sun, is at the centre
of the Solar system.

35.86.text:
trillions of asteroids and comets and a
few dwarf planets.

40.88.text:
The eight planets. Divided into four
planets like ours:

47.18.text:
and four gas giants:
Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus and Neptune.

54.11.text:
Mercury is the smallest and
lightest of all the planets.

56.96.text:
A Mercury year is shorter than the Mercury
day, which leads to

63.99.text:
Mercury does not have an
atmosphere or a moon.

68.94.text:
Venus is one of the brightest objects in
the Solar system and by far

72.53.text:
the hottest planet, with atmospheric
pressure that is

80.41.text:
An out-of-control greenhouse effect
means that Venus never

89.17.text: Venus also doesn’t have a moon.

93.19.text: Earth is our home and the only planet

95.69.text:
with temperatures that are moderate enough
to allow for a surplus of liquid water.

100.27.text:
Furthermore, it’s so far the only place
where life is known to exist.

110.16.text:
Mars is the second smallest planet
in the Solar system

112.87.text:
and hardly massive enough to keep a very
thin atmosphere.

116.72.text:
Its Olympus Mons is the largest
mountain in the Solar system,

119.78.text:
more than three times as high as Mount
Everest.

129.11.text:
Jupiter is the largest and most massive
planet in the Solar system.

133.23.text:
It consists largely of hydrogen and
helium

135.57.text:
and is the theatre for the largest and
most powerful storms we know.

141.10.text:
Its largest storm, the Great Red Spot,
is three times as large as Earth.

149.87.text:
Saturn is the second largest planet and
possesses the smallest density

155.55.text:
If you had a sufficiently large bathtub,
Saturn would swim in it.

160.41.text:
Saturn is also known for its extended,
very visible ring system.

168.09.text:
Uranus is the third largest planet
and one of the coldest.

172.51.text:
Of all the gas giants, it’s also
the smallest.

175.93.text:
The special thing about Uranus is that
its axis of rotation

178.72.text:
is tilted sideways in contrast to the
seven other planets.

186.44.text:
Neptune is the last planet in the Solar
system and is similar to Uranus.

191.23.text:
It’s so far removed from the Sun that
a Neptune year is 164 Earth years long.

198.30.text:
The highest wind speed ever measured
was in a storm on Neptune,

212.29.text: If we compare the sizes of the planets,

214.46.text:
the differences between them
become even clearer.

218.29.text:
Jupiter is the leader in terms of
size and weight;

222.78.text: small Mercury, on the other hand,

224.54.text:
is even smaller than one of Jupiter’s
moons, Ganymede.

228.59.text:
Jupiter is so massive that alone it
contains roughly 70% of the mass

233.13.text:
of all the other planets and has a massive
impact on its surroundings.

238.13.text:
That’s a blessing for Earth, since
Jupiter draws most of

241.40.text:
the dangerously large asteroids
that could wipe out life on Earth.

247.38.text:
But even Jupiter is a dwarf in
comparison to our star, the Sun.

252.33.text:
Calling it massive does not do
justice to the Sun.

255.73.text:
It makes up 99.86% of the mass
in our Solar system.

260.83.text:
For the most part, it consists of
hydrogen and helium.

263.88.text:
Only less than 2% is made up of
heavy elements, like oxygen or iron.

269.51.text:
At its core, the Sun fuses 620 million
tons of hydrogen each second

274.72.text:
and generates enough energy to satisfy
mankind’s needs for years.

281.58.text:
But not only the eight planets
orbit our Sun.

284.63.text:
Trillions of asteroids and comets
also circle it.

288.78.text:
Most of them are concentrated into
two belts:

291.89.text:
the asteroid belt between Mars and
Jupiter

295.13.text:
and the Kuiper belt at the edge of the
Solar system.

298.77.text:
These belts are home to countless
objects, some as large as a dust particle,

302.53.text: others the size of dwarf planets.

306.37.text:
The most well-known object in the
asteroid belt is Ceres;

309.18.text:
the most well-known objects in the Kuiper
belt are Pluto, Makemake and Haumea.

316.31.text: Usually we describe the asteroid belt as

318.98.text:
a dense collection of bodies that
constantly collide.

322.92.text:
But in fact, the asteroids are
distributed across an area that is

326.60.text:
so indescribably large that it’s even
difficult to see two asteroids at once.

332.76.text: Despite the billions of objects in them,

334.84.text:
the asteroid belts are fairly empty
places.

337.99.text:
And nonetheless, there are collisions
over and over again.

341.94.text:
The mass of both belts is also
unimpressive:

344.58.text:
the asteroid belt has a little less than
4% of our Moon’s mass, and

349.94.text:
the Kuiper belt is only between one 25th
and one 10th of Earth’s mass.

357.23.text:
One day, the Solar system will cease to
exist.

360.60.text:
The Sun will die, and Mercury, Venus and
maybe Earth too will be destroyed.

366.57.text:
In 500 million years it will become hotter
and hotter until at some point

375.27.text:
Then the Sun will grow and grow and
either swallow Earth

378.26.text: or at least turn it into a sea of lava.

384.42.text:
When it has burnt up all its fuel and
lost most of its mass,

387.56.text:
it will shrink to a white dwarf and burn
gently for a few billion more years

396.53.text:
Then, at the latest, life in the Solar
system will no longer be possible.

401.60.text: The Milky Way will not even notice it.

404.28.text:
A small part of it in one of its arms
will become just a tiny bit darker.

408.98.text:
And mankind will cease to exist
or leave the Solar system

414.09.text: in search of a new home.
